libp2p spec politics: https://github.com/libp2p/specs/pull/100#discussion_r267780488 …

SHOULD implies open spec where implementations may be unable to talk and still claim libp2p support

MUST implies closed spec where implementations are minimally able to talk but are must also support crypto they otherwise don't need

1106255511844986888.text: You can get a closer look at these logs real easy from the comfort of your own computer - networking, fork choice, blocks, attestations etc - by running the beacon node simulation you'll find here: https://github.com/status-im/nim-beacon-chain … - a personal #eth2 testnet!

1106255510385377282.text: The state transition we looked at last time (we've since updated to spec 0.4.0) is a small but important part of the full beacon node - check that out as well:https://twitter.com/jcksie/status/1101580118286389248 …

1106255508707729417.text: Underneath everything is a peer-to-peer network over which blocks and attestations are broadcast and where peers can ask each other for anything they missed. Nodes connect to each other, sync up and start working.pic.twitter.com/ehUkbGP0Di

1106255503196409856.text: Each beacon node can serve multiple validators - how many depends on its resources - for each validator there's an additional shard to sync and maintain - that's where the real action will be happening: contracts, accounts, etc. Small chains are easier to demo however pic.twitter.com/JFptPlFgcr

1106255497651503105.text: It's the internet and there's plenty of fake news out there (or bugs in this case). Fortunately though, we're validating things and voters are intelligent enough to ignore the noise. What a beautiful world - everyone keeps voting for the previous holder of the seat.pic.twitter.com/u4wUrkdq34

1106255491880181760.text: Of course we also get a few seconds of fame when we have to produce a block. Notice there's only 1 attestation in there? It's the magic of BLS aggregate signatures allowing us to combine all identical votes - more validators can participate without chain bloat!pic.twitter.com/H64ZqnslGv

1106255486230450176.text: Fork choice starts from the most recent justified block we know about, based on head candidates we've received so far - when we select a new head, that might feed back into selecting a new finalized block, and therefore throwing out some previously viable justified candidates.pic.twitter.com/9BS7as1DxA

1106255479896973312.text: It's all very stressful. There's a tight schedule to follow, and you might fall behind, specially during the heavy epoch processing which is done every few slots. Good news though, we managed to finalize an epoch starting at slot 5152 when updating the head.pic.twitter.com/CBUiy6VcHJ

1106255473752322049.text: Sleep, eat, work. Repeat. Boring life. See the time stamps? Roughly 6 seconds between each block. Also on display the joy of distributed systems - there's a new block, but we're still getting votes for its parent. Sometimes it's sleep,  eat, work, yesterdays work.pic.twitter.com/SLpp6oVwrL

1106255468262031361.text: Thus, going back to the block B9F2ED1F, we see how its parent is D1EA5A6B - just before we received it, the parent was being voted on. Looks like it won the election this time around.pic.twitter.com/OL9dYB2Nm0

1106255462163468288.text: Why select this block, and not another? To find out, we go back to the latest justified block and run a vote count, or fork choice, on all its descendants. We'll do this when we're about to attest or propose a new block capturing that moment in time using the best info available.pic.twitter.com/WvpVzi0v2N

1106255456761249792.text: Where did the block come from? Well, we received it from the network, resolved it by linking it back to a parent we know about and validated it by applying it successfully to the state of that parent - it is now a candidate for head selection!pic.twitter.com/L54VuuMPth

1106255451631636481.text: Apart from the head block, rewards will be handed out for getting a few other pieces of data right -  including nailing justification as per Casper: https://ethresear.ch/t/beacon-chain-casper-mini-spec/2760 …. 10 validators connected to this node, but only 3 are voting this round - it's split by shard.

1106255449249251328.text: The beacon node establishes the current head of the list effectively by voting, or attesting, as it's called here. Time progresses in slots, and for every slot, we broadcast and collect votes. Several nodes are voting for block B9F2ED1F, us included.pic.twitter.com/VTRTusumN0

1106255441082937345.text: So what does an #eth2 beacon node actually do, in practice? Well, here's a tweet storm to find out. We'll follow the logs of a node backwards, just like following a block chain that effectively is a singly linked list going back in time. Reverse engineering, like :)

1101580180194279425.text: Want to try this with your own chain parameters? Easy-peasy, all you need to do is run our state sim that will generate JSONs using the Nimbus implementation of the #eth2 state transition function:https://github.com/status-im/nim-beacon-chain/blob/master/research/state_sim.nim …

1101580178944344066.text: This particular run was done using spec release 0.3.0, with 1024 shards, 64 slots per epoch and 64 validators - the small validator count doesn't make much sense as the stake is too low for security, and in fact, the chain is unable to advance properly at such low counts..

1101580176943665154.text: Finally, eth1_data is used to keep track of deposits on the Eth1 chain that allow new validators to join the system.pic.twitter.com/Y8f0xmslsW

1101580169154887685.text: Most slot processing is about collecting work for the big epoch update that happens every 64 slots - thus part of the state is dedicated to collecting work to be done.. Attestations are used to tally votes on chain state and cross-links.pic.twitter.com/uDl3Ub6Gh9

1101580159029837824.text: Being a proposer means creating blocks that form the block chain. In the blocks, you'll find attestations and other coordination data. Blocks hold a merkle root of the state of the same slot, so only historical block roots can be added to the state!pic.twitter.com/x3JS8V4mrH

1101580151580753921.text: The randomness is used to seed a shuffling algorithm that selects future voting committees and block proposers, allowing them some time to sync the shard chain they will be working with.pic.twitter.com/plw4MUQiPG

1101580143133368320.text: Much of the eth2 security depends on there being good random numbers available - these are produced using a BLS-based RANDAO game that mixes in randomness from values that proposers reveal in every block.pic.twitter.com/rKkbCxoi5x

1101580136208629760.text: As validators do their work, they get rewarded or penalized - small rewards for good work, small penalties for staying home and drinking  and big penalties for cheating. What happened with the first validator? probably a bug - the state sim is excellent for finding those pic.twitter.com/C3SV4v8YoX

1101580128000315392.text: Slot numbers are increasing, which is a good sanity check - they're very big, owing to a.. uhh.. pragmatic approach to avoid unsigned integer underflows in the spec. The list of validators in the genesis state comes from eth1 deposits - #eth2 starts when there are enough manypic.twitter.com/hGmvNmZDFI

1101580118286389248.text: A tweet storm about the first 64 epochs in the life of the #eth beacon chain state, in a rosy world where nothing but love flows from the validators...
